problem_text: Given a frequency table of hospital stays, construct a boxplot and identify the five-number summary.
solution_text: Minimum = 5, Q1 = 6, Median = 7, Q3 = 8, Maximum = 21 (based on frequency counts).

problem_text: Apply the 1.5 × IQR rule to the hospital stay data. Identify any outliers.
solution_text: Calculate IQR = Q3 – Q1. Multiply by 1.5. Add/subtract from Q1/Q3 to determine thresholds. Flag 21 as an outlier.

problem_text: The same data has a mean of 7.42 and standard deviation of 2.37. Use the 2-standard deviation rule to identify outliers.
solution_text: Determine bounds: 7.42 ± 2(2.37) ≈ [2.68, 12.16]. Flag any values outside this range.

problem_text: Explain why Method A (IQR) might detect more outliers than Method B (standard deviation) in skewed distributions.
solution_text: IQR is not affected by extreme values. Standard deviation pulls toward the mean, under-identifying in right-skewed data.
